title: Harvey Hendrick
text:
Harvey "Gink" Hendrick (November 9, 1897 – October 29, 1941) was an American <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> player who played for several different teams during an eleven-year career.
Early years.
Born near <a href="Mason%2C%20Tennessee">Mason, Tennessee</a> on November 9, 1897 to Richard T. and Nannie Harvey Hendrick, Hendrick went to elementary school in <a href="Brownsville%2C%20Tennessee">Brownsville, Tennessee</a>. Hendrick attended <a href="University%20preparatory%20school">preparatory school</a> at Fitzgerald & Clarke School in <a href="Tullahoma%2C%20Tennessee">Tullahoma, Tennessee</a>; also attended by the likes of Vanderbilt football greats <a href="Lynn%20Bomar">Lynn Bomar</a> and <a href="Hek%20Wakefield">Hek Wakefield</a>. He then attended <a href="Vanderbilt%20University">Vanderbilt University</a>, playing <a href="American%20football">football</a> and baseball for the Commodores. He was a favored target of <a href="Jess%20Neely">Jess Neely</a> on the football team.
Professional baseball.
He signed with the <a href="Memphis%20Chicks%20%28Southern%20Association%29">Memphis Chicks</a> after graduating from Vanderbilt, but was released from the team before playing a game. He began his professional career with the <a href="Chattanooga%20Lookouts">Chattanooga Lookouts</a> in 1921, and had a .274 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> in 141 games. He followed that up the following year with a .311 batting average in 134 games for the <a href="Galveston%20Sand%20Crabs">Galveston Sand Crabs</a>. During the offseason, shortly after being signed by the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a>, Hendrick was traded to the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a> with <a href="George%20Pipgras">George Pipgras</a> for <a href="Al%20DeVormer">Al DeVormer</a>. He made his major league debut with the <a href="1923%20New%20York%20Yankees%20season">Yankees in 1923</a>, where he had a .273 batting average in 37 games and had one <a href="at-bat">at-bat</a> in the <a href="1923%20World%20Series">1923 World Series</a>.
After one more year with New York where he played in 40 games, he joined the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a> and played in 25 games for them. Hendrick spent 1926 in the minor leagues with the <a href="Newark%20Bears%20%28International%20League%29">Newark Bears</a>, then joined the <a href="Brooklyn%20Robins">Brooklyn Robins</a>, arriving days before everyone else for <a href="spring%20training">spring training</a>, as the team planned to use him as a <a href="utility%20player">utility player</a>. In 1927, he had a .310 average and 29 <a href="stolen%20base">stolen base</a>s in 128 games, then followed that up a .318 average in 1928, a .354 average in 1929 which was ninth in the <a href="National%20League">National League</a> along with 14 <a href="home%20run">home run</a>s and 82 <a href="runs%20batted%20in">runs batted in</a>, and a .257 average in 1930. After playing in one game for the Robins in 1931, he was traded to the <a href="Cincinnati%20Reds">Cincinnati Reds</a> for <a href="Mickey%20Heath">Mickey Heath</a>.
In 137 games for the Reds, he had a .314 batting average. Hendrick split 1932 with the Reds and <a href="St.%20Louis%20Cardinals">St. Louis Cardinals</a>, who he was traded to during the season for <a href="Chick%20Hafey">Chick Hafey</a>. He then finished his career with the <a href="Chicago%20Cubs">Chicago Cubs</a> in 1933 and the <a href="Philadelphia%20Phillies">Philadelphia Phillies</a> in 1934.
In an 11-year major league career, Hendrick batted .308 (896-2910) with 434 <a href="runs%20scored">runs scored</a>, 48 <a href="home%20runs">home runs</a> and 413 <a href="RBI">RBI</a> in 922 <a href="games%20played">games played</a>. His <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a> was .364 and <a href="slugging%20percentage">slugging percentage</a> was .443. He surpassed the .300 mark four times.
Death.
Hendrick died by his own hand, shooting himself in his <a href="Covington%2C%20Tennessee">Covington, Tennessee</a> home, on October 29, 1941. He was 43.
